titleStmt.title: Logical structure of fuzzy IF-THEN rules

analytic.title: Logical structure of fuzzy IF-THEN rules

biblStruct.note: Received 22 June 2005; received in revised form 23 February 2006; accepted 28 February 2006

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper provides a logical basis for manipulation with fuzzy IF-THEN rules. Our theory is wide enough and it encompasses not only finding a conclusion by means of the compositional rule of inference due to Lotfi A. Zadeh but also other kinds of approximate reasoning methods, e.g., perception-based deduction, provided that there exists a possibility to characterize them within a formal logical system. In contrast with other approaches employing variants of multiple-valued first-order logic, the approach presented here employs fuzzy type theory of V. Novák which has sufficient expressive power to present the essential concepts and results in a compact, elegant and justifiable form. Within the effectively formalized representation developed here, based on a complete logical system, it is possible to reconstruct numerous well-known properties of CRI-related fuzzy inference methods, albeit not from the analytic point of view as usually presented, but as formal derivations of the logical system employed. The authors are confident that eventually all relevant knowledge about fuzzy inference methods based on fuzzy IF-THEN rule bases will be represented, formalized and backed up by proof within the well-founded logical representation presented here. An immediate positive consequence of this approach is that suddenly all elements of a fuzzy inference method based on fuzzy IF-THEN rules are 'first class citizenś of the representation: there are clear, logically founded definitions for fuzzy IF-THEN rule bases to be consistent, complete, or independent.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: This paper has been inspired by the works of Thiele [38,39], who proposed to use the concepts of logic such as model, consistency, extension, consequence and others for the analysis of fuzzy IF-THEN rules. Our main goal in this paper is to formalize the meaning of fuzzy IF-THEN rules. There is an extensive literature devoted to this task (see, for example, [2,10,13,16,[31][32][33] and elsewhere). Fuzzy IF-THEN rules are usually taken as specific characterization of dependencies among objects. The basic tool is then either pure fuzzy set theory or the predicate fuzzy logic. For example, Hájek in his book [10] developed a theory of fuzzy IF-THEN rules within many-sorted first-order BL-fuzzy logic extended by a special binary fuzzy equivalence predicate. Similarly, Perfilieva shows in [32,33] that sets of fuzzy IF-THEN rules can be modelled using special formulas of fuzzy predicate logic being generalization of the classical boolean conjunctive and disjunctive normal forms. The goal in these and similar works is to provide a working theory suitable for technical applications, the main problem of which is to find a sufficiently precise approximation of some function. It should be stressed that none of the cited authors considered fuzzy IF-THEN rules as linguistic expressions.

For the advanced applications, for example in robotics or artificial intelligence, however, it is a challenge to take fuzzy IF-THEN rules as genuine expressions of natural language and to capture their meaning from this point of view. A good reason for this effort is the goal to develop human-like behaving robots. First-order predicate logic, however, is insufficient for this task because it does not allow to formalize the concepts of intension and extension. Though fuzzy IF-THEN rules have fairly simple linguistic structure and so, first-order logic can sometimes overcome this problem, further extension to more complicated linguistic phenomena would hardly be possible. This is the main reason why we decided to employ the fuzzy type theory (FTT) of Novák [21] which has sufficient expressive power to present the essential concepts and results in a compact, elegant and justifiable form. Our wider goal is to develop a concise and sufficiently general theory of the fuzzy IF-THEN rules that would encompass not only the above mentioned technical means for approximation of functions but also formalization of the linguistic meaning of these rules when taken as special expressions of natural language. Our theory also fits well the idea of developing a precisiated natural language (PNL) presented by Zadeh in [41], i.e., to find a reasonable mathematical model of the meaning of a certain subset of natural language expressions that could be used in various applications and that would at the same time comply with the human way of understanding them.

When dealing with the meaning of fuzzy IF-THEN rules, one cannot avoid the problem of solvability of fuzzy relation equations. This theory has been originated by Sanchez in [36] and further elaborated by many authors, for example DiNola et al. [4], Gottwald [8], Gottwald et al. [9], Klawonn [12,26], Novák et al. [30], Perfilieva and Lehmke [34], Perfilieva and Tonis [35] and others. The authors in [34] show that the problem of solvability of fuzzy relation equations has a deeper meaning, namely that it corresponds to consistency of the description of the given problem. These results became motivation for part of our analysis contained in this paper. We will show that this problem is connected with inherent meaning of the text (we speak about implicit intension of the linguistic description). Having sound formal logical theory at disposal, we may study its relation to the meaning (intension) of the rules themselves. Moreover, we may introduce clear, logically founded definitions for fuzzy IF-THEN rule bases to be consistent, complete, or independent and to consider also dependent IF-THEN rules that can be derived from rule bases (and so, be proved to be redundant).

Our theory is wide enough and it encompasses not only finding a conclusion by means of the compositional rule of inference due to Zadeh [40] but also other kinds of approximate reasoning methods, e.g., the perception-based logical deduction (see [22,28]), provided that it is possible to characterize them within a formal logical system. Within the effectively formalized representation developed here (based on a complete logical system), it is possible to reconstruct numerous well-known properties of CRI-related fuzzy inference methods, albeit not from the analytic point of view as usually presented, but as formal derivations of the logical system employed.

The paper is organized as follows: first we characterize the fuzzy IF-THEN rules as special linguistic expressions starting with their components. In Section 4 we briefly remind some main concepts of the FTT. However, for full understanding to this paper, we suppose the reader to be acquainted with the papers [21,17]. Section 5 is devoted to formalization of the meaning of a single fuzzy IF-THEN rule and the following section to formalization of the meaning of systems of them.

It is important to stress that our paper in a certain sense summarizes and systematizes results scattered over the literature on fuzzy IF-THEN rules and also the related problem of fuzzy relation equations. Most theorems are proved syntactically, some of them are syntactical formulation of the known properties that were derived on the basis of more narrow assumptions and often without logical considerations. Our results often contribute to deeper understanding of the given phenomenon in a wider context.

div.head: Preliminaries
div.p: By a fuzzy set we mean a function A : U -→ L where U is a universe and L is a support of a given structure of truth values. The latter set coincides with the set of truth values for the FTT (see Section 4). To express that A is a fuzzy set in U, we will sometimes write A ⊂ ∼ U . A (binary) fuzzy relation is a fuzzy set R ⊂ ∼ U × V , i.e., a function R : U × V -→ L.
The composition of a fuzzy set A ⊂ ∼ U and a fuzzy relation
div.formula: R ⊂ ∼ U × V is a fuzzy set B ⊂ ∼ V given by B(v) = u∈U (A(u) ⊗ R(u, v)), (1
div.p: where ⊗ is a suitable product operation (a t-norm)-see Section 4. We usually write (1) as
A fuzzy relation equation is Eq. ( 2) for the unknown fuzzy relation R. If such R exists then we say that the fuzzy relation equation ( 2) is solvable.
Let a set of couples of fuzzy sets A i , B i , i = 1, . . . , m be given. This set leads to a system of fuzzy relation equations
for the unknown fuzzy relation R. If such R exists then we say that system (3) is solvable.

div.head: Fuzzy IF-THEN rules as special linguistic expressions
Adjectival predications
div.p: In this paper, we will consider a specific part of natural language, namely adjectival clauses and adjectival predications. Adjectival clause consists of an adjective and, possibly, a modifier. For example, red, very big, full of spare parts, rather sad, totally empty, roughly medium, etc.

A significant constituent of adjectival clauses is formed by the, so called, evaluating linguistic expressions (e.g., very small, extremely long, roughly medium, etc.) that are special expressions used for characterization of a position on some bounded ordered scale (see [19,24,25,31]). Note that we may also consider adjectival phrases 3 that are phrases with an adjective as their head (e.g., full of spare parts). Adjectival phrases and clauses are, in essence, names of properties of objects.

Adjectival clauses and phrases may occur as premodifiers to a noun (a very tall man, a container full of spare parts), or as adjectival predications, i.e., expressions affiliating adjectives to a noun, for example the temperature is very high, the container is full of spare parts, my friend is extremely intelligent, etc. We will take both these expressions as synonymous and, in the sequel, deal with adjectival predications only. We will not go into further details of their structure since they are unnecessary for the general theory of fuzzy IF-THEN rules discussed further. Throughout this paper, we will denote the considered expressions of natural language by script letters A, B, R, . . .

div.head: Definition 1.
div.p: (i) Let A be an adjectival clause. The linguistic expression
div.formula: noun is A (4)
div.p: is an adjectival predication. (ii) Let Ā and B be adjectival predications. Then the following are compound adjectival predications:
div.formula: (a) R A := Ā and B, 4 (b) R O := Ā or B, (c) R I := IF Ā THEN B.
div.p: In the case of R I , the part before THEN is called antecedent and after it consequent (possibly also succedent). Note that in more complicated cases, the antecedent may be formed from R A as well as R O , for example "IF temperature is high or pressure is very low THEN . . .", or "IF road is wide and very well preserved or bridge is new or strong THEN . . .", etc.

By S, we denote the set of linguistic expressions consisting of adjectival clauses and adjectival predications. Note that in the applications of fuzzy logic, only that part of S consisting of evaluating linguistic expressions and predications is till now employed (mostly without the attempt to penetrate into their linguistic meaning).

div.head: Fuzzy IF-THEN rules
div.p: The ' noun ' is often unimportant in the applications. Therefore, we will replace it by some variable X whose values are not the objects themselves but only their features, such as height, volume, tension, size, abstract degrees of beauty, temperature, etc. This leads us to the concept of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule which is a kind of "abstracted" compound adjectival predication. Definition 2. By fuzzy IF-THEN rule we understand either of the compound adjectival predications R I and R A taken in the form
div.formula: R A := X is A AND Y is B, (5) R I := IF X is A THEN Y is B, (6
div.p: where X, Y represent features of objects.

The adjectival predications R A and R I linguistically characterize (or express existence of) some relation between arbitrary objects x and y named by the respective nouns, that have properties named by A and B, respectively.

The difference between R A and R I consists in the extent of their operation. If we analyse their meaning, we find that R I characterizes an arbitrary (conditional) relation. This means that if objects represented by X have the property named by A then they are in relation with objects represented by Y which have the property named by B; if the objects X do not have A then the relation with the objects Y is accepted but not further specified. Moreover, the objects Y are determined or influenced by the objects X via this relation (we usually say that X is independent and Y dependent variable).

On the other hand, R A characterizes only positive part of such relation, i.e., just objects having the property named by A are in relation with objects having the property named by B. Thus, R A can be understood as a special (essential) part of R I . Of course, fuzzy IF-THEN rules are intrinsically vague and so, the relation may not be characterized precisely by them.

The reader may be embarrassed that we call R A also a fuzzy IF-THEN rule despite the fact that it is a (symmetric) conjunction of adjectival predications. We think that this is a certain linguistic licence since, as explained, in both cases we characterize some relation in which independent and dependent constituents are clearly distinguished. As explained above, R A can be, moreover, understood a part of R I and consequently, taken as nonsymmetric. We must admit, however, that this justification is based on informal semantic arguments and from the formal point of view, R A is indeed symmetric. We are unable to fix this problem more satisfactorily on the present stage of knowledge.

The symbols R A and R I will be used as metavariables for the corresponding forms of fuzzy IF-THEN rules ( 5) and (6), respectively. If the concrete form of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule is unimportant then we simply write R.
In addition, we may also introduce a simplified form of the compound adjectival predication R O by
div.formula: R O := X is A OR Y is B. (7
div.p: This predication, however, characterizes a very weak form of a relation between X and Y and so, we will not take it as a fuzzy IF-THEN rule.

div.head: Topic and focus of fuzzy IF-THEN rules
div.p: One of the most important linguistic phenomena is division of the linguistic meaning of sentences into topic and focus. Informally, the topic is the theme, i.e., what is spoken about while focus is that part which conveys a new information.

Every sentence is assumed to have a focus since otherwise it could not convey relevant information. However, there can be sentences without topic. The division into topic and focus for one sentence is not unique. It depends on several aspects, which we will not discuss here. Let us only remark that this fact is one of the sources of extreme power of natural language to characterize real world phenomena. The interested reader is referred to [11,37].
Since the fuzzy IF-THEN rules are also special natural language sentences, they have topic and focus. Their structure, of course, is very simple and so, we can define them unambiguously as follows.
Definition 3. Let R be a fuzzy IF-THEN rule (5) or (6). Then its topic is formed by the adjectival predication 'X is A' and its focus by 'Y is B'.

Let us remark that the surface form of ( 5) is symmetric and so, it may be doubtful, what is topic and what focus. The clue lays in the above discussed distinction between independent and dependent variable. Hence, the topic is always formed by the part of fuzzy IF-THEN rule, that gives evidence about independent variable. Of course, this cannot follow from the rule itself but from the wider sense given by a more structured text. Since these questions are out of the scope of this paper, we suppose that the information on which variable is independent and which dependent is given from outside.

div.head: Fuzzy type theory
div.p: The main tool for the logical analysis of fuzzy IF-THEN rules in this paper is the FTT. In this section, we will very briefly overview some of the main points of the FTT. The detailed explanation of FTT can be found in [17,18,21]. The classical type theory is in details described in [1].

div.head: Basic syntactical elements
div.p: Let , o be distinct objects. The set of types is the smallest set Types satisfying:
div.formula: (i) , o ∈ Types, (ii) if , ∈ Types then ( ) ∈ Types.
div.p: The type represents elements, o truth values.

Each formula in the FTT is assigned a type ∈ Types written as its subscript. The primitive symbols are variables x , . . . , special constants c , . . . , (o ) , o(oo) (description operators), the symbol and various kinds of brackets. Among special constant we put E (o ) (equality), C (oo)o (conjunction) and D oo (Baaz delta).
A set of formulas of type ∈ Types, denoted by Form , is a smallest set satisfying:
div.formula: (i) Variables x ∈ Form and constants c ∈ Form . (ii) If B ∈ Form and A ∈ Form then (BA) ∈ Form . (iii) If A ∈ Form then x A ∈ Form .
div.p: If A ∈ Form is a formula of the type ∈ Types then we usually write A . On the other hand, to make the notation more transparent, we will often write in advance that, e.g., x ∈ Form and then write simply x instead of x . Note that in FTT, all elements of the syntax are formulas (in the literature, formulas are quite often called -terms, instead) including variables or connectives.
Formulas of type o (truth value) can be joined by the following connectives (i.e., also formulas): (g) Special connectives

div.head: Notation
div.p: To simplify the notation as much as possible, which means especially to minimize the number of brackets, we will use the following conventions in the sequel.
Priority of logical connectives:
Furthermore, we will also use the dot convention as follows: the formula A • B is equivalent to A(B). For example, the formula
div.formula: x • Ax ∧ ∧ ∧ •Bx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ C is equivalent to x(Ax ∧ ∧ ∧ (Bx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ C)).

div.head: The structure of truth values
div.p: The structure of truth values for FTT is supposed to form a complete IMTL -algebra (see [6]), which is a complete residuated lattice
fulfilling the prelinearity condition

and, moreover, its negation function ¬a = a → 0 is involutive, i.e., ¬¬a = a holds for all a ∈ L. The (Baaz) is a special unary operation of 0 -1 projection. For its general definition, see, e.g., [10]. In case that L is linearly ordered, is defined by
div.formula: (a) = 1 if a = 1, 0 otherwise. (9
div.p: It is known that MTL-algebras are algebras (the negation needs not be involutive) of left-continuous t-norms. An example of left-continuous t-norm with involutive negation is nilpotent minimum.

In this paper we suppose L to have a stronger structure, namely, that of MV algebra. Even more, we will suppose it to be just Łukasiewicz MV -algebra (i.e., the standard MV algebra on [0, 1]; cf. [10,31]). In this case,
div.formula: L = [0, 1], a ⊗ b = 0 ∨ (a + b -1) is Łukasiewicz conjunction, a → b = 1 ∧ (1 -a + b)
div.p: is Łukasiewicz implication and is operation (9). At the same time, be aware that a lot of propositions presented below hold also in IMTL -algebra.

div.head: Syntax
div.p: The syntax of FTT consists of definitions of fundamental formulas, axioms and inference rules. A more detailed presentation would be too extensive and so, we will repeat only some of the main points.
The IMTL -FTT has 17 axioms that may be divided into the following subsets: fundamental equality axioms, truth structure axioms, quantifier axioms and axioms of descriptions.
Fundamental equality axioms are the following:
div.formula: (FT I 1) (x ≡ y ) ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ (f x ≡ f y ), (FT I 2 1 ) (∀x )(f x ≡ g x ) ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ (f ≡ g ), (FT I 2 2 ) (f ≡ g ) ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ (f x ≡ g x ), (FT I 3) ( x B )A ≡ C
div.p: where C is obtained from B by replacing all free occurrences of x in it by A , provided that A is substitutable to B for x (lambda conversion),

Further axioms characterize the structure of truth values. These axioms (altogether 11) assure that the predicate IMTL fuzzy logic with the connective is included in FTT, i.e., all theorems of the former are provable also in FTT. For the case of Ł-FTT (Łukasiewicz FTT), these axioms cover the Rose-Roser's axioms of Łukasiewicz logic (for the details, see [23]).
Specific and important axiom for provability properties among them is the axiom
div.formula: (FT I 6) (A o ≡ ) ≡ A o .
div.p: The quantifier axiom is
div.formula: (FT I 16) (∀x )(A o ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B o ) ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ (A o ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ (∀x )B o ) where x is not free in A o .
div.p: A special constant used in FTT is the description operator (o ) . For its interpretation see below. The description operator is tied with the fuzzy equality E (o ) by means of the following axioms of descriptions:

There are two inference rules in FTT, namely: A theory T is a set of formulas of type o (determined by a subset of special axioms, as usual). Provability is defined as usual. If T is a theory and A o a formula then T ٛA o means that A o is provable in T. Note that the inference rules of modus ponens and generalization are derived rules of FTT. Note also, that Ł-FTT is not supposed to contain logical constants (names of truth values) as is, e.g., in Ev Ł (fuzzy logic with evaluated syntax)-see [31]. However, it is possible to introduce them if necessary.

div.head: Semantics
div.p: Let J be a language of FTT. A frame for J is a tuple
div.formula: M = (M , = ) ∈Types , L(10)
div.p: so that the following holds:
(i) The L is a structure of truth values (IMTL or Łukasiewicz algebra).
(ii) = is a fuzzy equality on M and = ∈ M (o ) for every ∈ Types.

Recall that if is a type then the corresponding set M contains (not necessarily all) functions f : M -→ M . We put M o = L and assume that each set M oo ∪ M (oo)o contains all the operations from L . Let p be an assignment of elements from M to variables from the language J. An interpretation I M is a function that assigns every formula A , ∈ Types and every assignment p a corresponding element, that is, a function (or element) of the type . With respect to the above remark, a general model is a frame M such that
div.formula: I M p (A ) ∈ M (11
div.p: holds true. This means that each set M from the frame M has enough elements so that the interpretation of each formula A ∈ Form is always defined in M. A frame M is a model of a theory T if all its axioms are true in the degree 1 in M. If A o is true in the degree 1 in all models of T then we write T A o .
The following completeness theorem can be proved in FTT.

div.head: Theorem 1 (completeness). (a) A theory T is consistent iff it has a general model M. (b) For every theory T and a formula
div.formula: A o T ٛA o iff T A o .
div.p: A special constant of the language J is the above mentioned description operator (o ) . Its interpretation a certain operation assigning to each normal fuzzy set in the universe M an element from its kernel (cf. [17]). Such an operation is in fuzzy set theory called defuzzification.
We also define a special operator
div.formula: z A o := (o ) ( z A o )
div.p: that picks up an element of type such that the formula A o is true in the degree 1 for it (i.e., it belongs to the kernel of the fuzzy set z A o ). The picked up element is typical for the formula A o (i.e., it is a prototype that surely has the property represented by A o ).

In this paper we also speak about contexts (possible worlds) that refer to specific types. In case of evaluating expressions, these types have the form o (cf. Section 5.6). In general, these types may be even more complicated. Because of larger variety of possibilities, we will use the general symbol W for the set of all contexts.

div.head: Formalization of the meaning of a single fuzzy IF-THEN rule
Introduction
div.p: Our main goal in this paper is to formalize the meaning of fuzzy IF-THEN rules. As mentioned in the Introduction, there already exist formal logical theories of them (see, for example, [10,32,33]). However, none of them covers their linguistic meaning and, in fact, it describes only extensions (see below). More focus on the linguistic side of the fuzzy IF-THEN rules can be found in the book [31]. The theory of their meaning is there also formed within first-order fuzzy logic, but in the generalized form that adds evaluation to formulas also on the syntactic level (we speak about fuzzy logic with evaluated syntax). It is demonstrated that this logic can already capture the distinction between intension and extension. The formalism is clear but more complicated. Because further extension of these theories to more complicated linguistic phenomena is hardly possible we decided to use FTT in this paper.

First, we will fix some formal language J of FTT. For our explanation, it is unnecessary to define explicitly all its special symbols. Therefore, when writing A ∈ J for some symbol A we silently assume that such a symbol has already been introduced in the language J.

Furthermore, we will suppose to work in some formal theory T of FTT within the language J. This means that certain specific formulas are provable in T. However, we will not specify explicitly axioms of T since we do not need them. Hence, T is arbitrary formal theory in which the formulas in concern are provable. If the reader feels uncomfortable with this, he/she may assume that if a new formula is said to be provable but without explicit reference to its proof then it can be just taken as an axiom of T.

To simplify notation, we will use special variables (formulas) for specific types only. Namely, we will introduce special types , , . . . for contexts (possible worlds) and use variables w, w , . . . for formulas of this type, i.e., w ∈ Form , w ∈ Form , . . . . More precise explanation is provided in Sections 5.6 and 5.7. Furthermore, variables x, y are always formulas of some types , , . . . that represent objects of various kinds.

div.head: Intension of adjectival clauses
div.p: When speaking about meaning of an adjectival clause, we must distinguish between its intension and extension. We will follow the generally accepted way how these concepts are mathematically modelled (cf., e.g., [7] and elsewhere), i.e., intension is a function assigning to each possible world and to each object a truth value. In other words, each possible world is assigned a class of objects. Extension is then the class of objects in a concrete possible world. This simple idea fits the requirement that intension does not depend on a concrete possible world while extension does. For the reasons that become clear later, we will prefer the term context to possible world.

Let A be an adjectival clause. We will interpret it by a formula A ∈ Form (o ) which represents a function assigning to each context (possible world) a fuzzy set. Clearly, the latter is the extension of A in the given context.

div.head: Definition 4.
div.p: Let A be a linguistic expression and w ∈ Form be a context. Then intension of A is a formula
div.formula: Int(A) := w x • A (o ) wx, (15
div.p: and extension of A in the context w is a formula
div.formula: Ext w (A) := Int(A)w. (16
div.p: Note that we immediately get
div.formula: ٛ Ext w (A) ≡ x • A (o ) wx(17)
div.p: using -conversion. Interpretation of intension ( 15) is a function from a set of all contexts W into the set of fuzzy sets in the universe M . Interpretation of extension ( 16) is a fuzzy subset of M . More precisely is the interpretation described in Section 5.15.

div.head: Intension of compound adjectival clauses
div.p: Let A, B be adjectival clauses (not predications!) such that
div.formula: Int(A) = w x • A (o ) wx, (18
Int(B) = w x • B (o ) w x. (19
div.p: where x ∈ Form . We may form compound clauses using the connectives 'and' and 'or'. For example, we may consider expressions such as "small and stout", "red or green", "beautiful and clever", "very hot and heavy", etc. Then
div.formula: Int(A and B) = w w x • A (o ) wx ∧ ∧ ∧ B (o ) w x, (20) Int(A or B) = w w x • A (o ) wx ∨ ∨ ∨ B (o ) w x, (21
div.p: where ∧ ∧ ∧ can be also replaced by & & &, and ∨ ∨ ∨ by ∇ ∇ ∇. 5Note that we deal here with different contexts w, w of the corresponding types and . They may be interpreted, for example, as "height" and "weight" of a "man", respectively where "man" is represented by object x ∈ Form .

div.head: Intension of adjectival predications
div.p: In this paper we usually do not consider concrete objects represented by nouns but replace them by variables X, Y, . . . whose values are features of objects discussed in Section 3.2. This simplification enables us to simplify also the model of meaning of the adjectival predications. For example, a small object, say a tree, a man, a barrel, etc. means that some feature measured on it (for example, size, volume, etc.) is close to a certain minimal value (e.g., 0). Similarly, green means that some feature (i.e., wavelength of the reflected light) falls in a fuzzy set of wavelengths that characterize the property of being "green" (something around 560 nm). Quite analogous reasoning can be made for other adjectives and adjectival clauses, such as full, very large, not too intelligent, extremely tasty, etc. Note that concrete objects are involved not directly but vicariously by their features!
The linguistic predication "X is A" should be read as "each value of X has the property named by A". Hence, we conclude that its intension is
div.formula: Int(X is A) = Int(A) = w x • A (o ) wx. (22
div.p: Of course, we may think of one specific element, say x. This gives an intension
div.formula: Int(X is A) = w • A (o ) wx.
div.p: However, if not stated otherwise, we will always consider case (22). Let us stress that the variable X stands either for a feature of an object, or for the object itself.

div.head: Explicit definition of intension of compound adjectival predications
div.p: Compound adjectival predications, in general, characterize relations between elements of different kinds having the respective properties. Let the linguistic predications 'X is A' and 'Y is B' have intensions (18) and (19), respectively (this assumption is justified by ( 22)) where, however, x ∈ Form and y ∈ Form for some, not necessarily different, types and , i.e., the elements in the predications may possibly be of different kinds. Then, we put
div.formula: Int(R A ) = Int(X is A and Y is B) := w w • x y • A (o ) wx & & & B (o ) w y, (23
Int(R O ) = Int(X is A or Y is B) := w w • x y • A (o ) wx ∨ ∨ ∨ B (o ) w y, (24
Int(R I ) = Int(IF X is A THEN Y is B) := w w • x y • A (o ) wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B (o ) w y. (25
div.p: It is possible to replace & & & by ∧ ∧ ∧, and ∨ ∨ ∨ by ∇ ∇ ∇.
In general, we will write intension of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule R (i.e., of the compound predication (5) or ( 6)) as
div.formula: Int(R) := w w • x y • A (o ) wx B (o ) w y, (26
div.p: where is either of the connectives & & &, ∧ ∧ ∧ or ⇒ ⇒ ⇒, and x ∈ Form and y ∈ Form . Note that intension ( 26) is a formula of type ((o ) ) .

div.head: Formal definition of contexts
div.p: Let us now discuss the meaning of the elements w ∈ W . In the literature on intensional logic (cf., for instance, [7,15]), w is taken as a possible world. This term has various interpretations such as "a state of the world at the given time moment and place", "the particular context in which the linguistic expression is used", or "a maximal consistent set of known (possible) facts". All of these interpretations are very wide and rough characterizations which can be arbitrarily specified to more and more details. However, mathematically speaking, w is some parameter which distinguishes concrete manifestations of the property in concern, disregarding its real meaning. In this paper, we will take w in a narrower (and more realistic) way: it is just a certain parameter characterizing a context (situation) in which the given linguistic expression is used.

As a special case, when dealing with evaluating expressions only then we may even specify context as follows: the type representing contexts is = o where is arbitrary type. Each context is in this case a function from the set of truth values to a set of objects of type . The reason for this definition is basically technical since it enables us to transfer properties to objects of various kinds without necessity to define them explicitly again and to specify once and again properties (such as ordering) that are defined already for truth values (for the details see [24]). In the sequel, we will not provide a detailed interpretation of contexts. In the formal theory, they will be identified with certain chosen types, whatever kind they are.

div.head: Local and general contexts
div.p: Let us now turn to definitions ( 23)- (25). One may be surprised by the fact that they represent functions which assign some truth value to each couple of contexts w, w and to each couple of elements x, y. This seems to contradict the general definition of intension in (15) where only one context (possible world) is considered. However, our definition means that each element x in the context w is in relation with some element y in the context w (in various degrees), i.e., these intensions represent a certain relation. Hence, couples of contexts in ( 23)-( 25) can be naturally explained. Namely, we can distinguish local and general contexts.

Local contexts are the parameters w. General contexts are couples or more generally, tuples of contexts w, w , . . . . Hence, we may read intensions ( 23)- (25) as functions from general contexts into the set of fuzzy sets, in general on M × M (i.e., fuzzy relations). Consequently, we returned to the generally accepted understanding to the concept of intension.
Let us remark that this enables us to consider general contexts even as certain complex structures over the set of contexts W. However, we will not develop this idea in this paper.

div.head: Remark
div.p: In [24,25], a logical theory of linguistic evaluating expressions has been developed. Besides others, the context was there identified with type o. This theory enables us to express in elegant form the meaning of fuzzy IF-THEN rules. For example, let us consider a rule IF X is roughly small THEN Y is very small, where X, Y are variables for elements of different kinds (recall that these may be some features such as temperature, speed, depth, etc.). We will in this section refer to specific formulas whose precise structure can be found see [24].

Let a formula Sm ∈ Form (o )( o) be a formal interpretation of the intension of the evaluating predication "X is linguistic hedge small" and let ∈ Form oo interpret the hedge roughly and the hedge very. Finally, let w ∈ Form o , w ∈ Form o be formulas representing contexts and x ∈ Form , y ∈ Form represent elements. Then intension of the above rule can be written as
div.formula: w w x y • Sm ( w x) ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ Sm ( w y), (27
div.p: where w x ≡ ( t o • x ≡ wt o ). It is noticeable on (27) that we have obtained a clear, unified and explicit interpretation of a very large class of fuzzy IF-THEN rules which consist of adjectives of the same kind (i.e., small, big, etc.) but refer to objects of different kinds; (27) can be the intension of a conditional expression, for example IF temperature is roughly small THEN pressure is very small. This is in perfect accordance with the way how people understand such expressions.

div.head: Special types
div.p: We will consider one fixed type for all objects (or their features-cf. the discussion above) whenever possible in the sequel. Furthermore, to simplify the notation, we will introduce the following symbols for special types:

• := (o ) -a type for intension, i.e., a function assigning a fuzzy set in a set of elements of type to each context. • := ((o ) ) -a type for intension of a relation, i.e., a function assigning a fuzzy relation to each couple of contexts that is, to each general context in the sense of Section 5.7.

div.head: Normality of intensions
div.p: Recall that we suppose a certain theory T to be given. We say that the intension Int(A) of a linguistic expression A is normal if the following is provable:

This means that in each context w we can find an element x that surely has the property named by the linguistic expression A. Note that if Int(A) is normal then by Lemma 2(d), also T ٛ(∀w)(∃x)A (o ) wx.

The normality assumption seems to be quite natural. Namely, it says that in each context there exists an element typical for the given property; it is a prototype of the latter. Indeed, we always can find a typical "red colour", "small value", "deep sea", "clever man", etc.

To characterize normality of the compound intension Int(R) (recall that it characterizes a relation), note that there are symmetric and non-symmetric relations. We say that a formula R represents a symmetric relation if the following is provable:

div.head: T ٛ(∀w)(∀w )(∀x)(∀y)(R ww xy ≡ Rww yx).
div.p: The intension Int(R) ≡ w w • x y • R ww xy is symmetric if the formula R represents a symmetric relation. Obviously, (23) and ( 24) are symmetric while (25) is not. Then we define normality of intension Int(R) as follows:
div.formula: (i) If Int(R) is symmetric then it is normal if T ٛ(∀w)(∀w )(∃x)(∃y) R ww xy. (ii) If Int(R) is asymmetric then it is normal if T ٛ(∀w)(∀w )(∀x)(∃y) R ww xy.
div.p: On the other hand, if the structure of R is determined by a suitable logical connective, then we may prove the following lemma on the basis of (28). Proof. This follows from Lemma 2(k) by properties of FTT and generalization.
In this paper we will suppose that all intensions including intensions of fuzzy IF-THEN rules are normal.

div.head: Explicit form of intension as a function of its parts
div.p: The generally accepted assumption required already by G. Frege is that the intension of an expression should be composed of the intensions of simpler expressions. We will show that this is the case also of our definitions.
Let us consider the following formula:
div.formula: S ( ) := z z • w w • x y • (z w)x (z w )y, (29
div.p: where is any of the connectives
Lemma 5. Let T be a theory in which Int(A), Int(B), Int(R) are defined in (18), ( 19) and (26), respectively. Then
div.formula: T ٛ Int(R) ≡ S ( ) Int(A) • Int(B). (30
div.p: Proof. We start with the provable formula ٛ Int(R) ≡ Int(R). Then, using three times -conversion and necessary renaming of the variables, we obtain
div.formula: ٛ Int(R) ≡ w w x y • ( w xA (o ) w x • wx w xA (o ) w ȳ • w y)
div.p: which is the right-hand side of (30) after rewriting.

It follows from this lemma that we can express intension of a compound linguistic predication (and thus, of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule) as a composition of intensions of its parts. This complies with the G. Frege's requirement.

Let us remark that we obtain traditional interpretation of fuzzy IF-THEN rules as certain fuzzy relations, as has been proposed by many authors (see the discussion in Introduction) immediately when either we fix one specific context, or omit variables for context from (29) at all. We demonstrate this explicitly in Section 5.15.

div.head: Implicit definition of intension of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule
div.p: In Sections 5.5 and 5.11, we explicitly constructed intension of a compound evaluating predication as a composition of intensions of its parts. In Section 3.1, we noted that the predications R A and R I characterize certain relation between properties of elements. Namely, they state that elements of X that have the property characterized by the intension Int(A) are in relation with those elements of Y that have the property characterized by the intension Int(B). Therefore, when considering the former, we should be able to obtain the latter. Consequently, the relation in concern should provide equality of these intensions.
This reasoning leads us to the requirement that there should exist a formula U ∈ Form in the language J (T ) such that the following is provable in the theory T:
div.formula: T ٛ Int(B) ≡ U • Int(A). (31
div.p: Let r be a variable of the type . We put
div.formula: T ٛ Ū( ) ≡ r z w y(∃x)(z wx & & & r ww xy). (32
div.p: Now, let R ∈ Form be a formula and put
By lambda conversion, the searched formula U is
div.formula: U := z • w y(∃x)(z wx & & & R ww xy). (33
div.p: The formula U in ( 33) is just a syntactical form of the, so called, compositional rule of inference (cf., e.g., [40]) widely used, in fuzzy control and elsewhere. If (31) is provable for U from (33) then we say that Int(R) := w w x y • R ww xy (34) is an implicit definition of an intension of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule containing the predications 'X is A' and 'Y is B'. Note that in this case, we cannot distinguish between R A and R I . In the sequel, when speaking about intension of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule without its more precise specification, we will generally refer to (34).

div.head: Extensionality of U
div.p: The formula U in (33) represents a function, i.e.,
div.formula: T ٛu ≡ U z & & & u ≡ U z ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ •u ≡ u
div.p: can be proved using transitivity of ≡. It is weakly extensional due to axioms of FTT. However, we can prove that it is even strongly extensional.
Lemma 6. The function U is strongly extensional, i.e.,
div.formula: T ٛz ≡ z ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ •U z ≡ U z .
div.p: Proof.
div.formula: (L.1) T ٛR ww xy ≡ R ww xy (reflexivity, properties of FTT) (L.2) T ٛ(z ≡ z ) ≡ (∀w)(∀x)(z wx ≡ z wx) (equivalence theorem) (L.3) T ٛ(∀w)(∀x)(z wx ≡ z wx) ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ •z wx ≡ z wx (substitution) (L.4) T ٛ(z ≡ z ) ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ (z wx & & & R ww xy ≡ z wx & & & R ww xy) (L.1, L.2, L.3, properties of FTT) (L.5) T ٛ(z ≡ z ) ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ •(∃x)(z wx & & & R ww xy) ≡ (∃x)(z wx & & & R ww xy) (L.4, generalization, Lemma 2(j), properties of FTT)
div.p: This property is quite important since it demonstrates that the compositional rule of inference which is obtained when interpreting U in some model has good properties. On the other hand, as will be seen in below, these properties may be too strong so that if we try to construct implicit intension of a linguistic description (that is, a system of fuzzy IF-THEN rules as a whole) then such a function may not exist in the given formal system.

div.head: The correspondence with fuzzy relation equations
div.p: Lemma 7. Let Int(R) be formula (34) and Then ( 35) is obtained by -conversion and the equality theorem. If (35) holds then we use the rule of generalization for w and y and Lemma 2(i). Finally, we apply the equality theorem.
div.formula: U := Ū( ) Int(R). Then (a) T ٛU ≡ z • w y • (∀w)(∃x)(z wx & & & R ww xy). (b) (31) is provable in T iff T ٛB w y ≡ (∃x)(A wx & & & R ww xy). (35
) (c) If (31) is provable in T then T ٛB w y ≡ (∀w)(∃x)(A wx & & & R ww xy). (36
div.p: (c) follows from (b) by generalization.

div.head: Let us denote
div.formula: Û := Ū( ) • Int(R I ), Ȗ := Ū( ) • Int(R A ). Lemma 8. (a) T ٛ Û ≡ z w y • (∃x)(z wx & & & A wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B w y). (b) T ٛ Ȗ ≡ z w y • (∃x)(z wx & & & A wx & & & B w y).
div.p: Proof. This follows from Lemma 7(a) by -conversion.

The following theorem is a syntactic formulation of the basic theorem for solution of one fuzzy relation equation that was first proved by Sanchez in [36]. Syntactically in BL-fuzzy logic, it has been proved in [30]. Our theorem below is still generalization of these results.
div.formula: T ٛ(∃x)(A wx & & & R ww xy) ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ (∃x)(A wx & & & •A wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B w y).
div.p: From this and ( 35) we obtain
div.formula: T ٛB w y ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ (∃x)(A wx & & & •A wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B w y).

div.head: The converse implication follows from the provable formula ٛx
div.p: Then (b) follows from the properties of FTT and the equality theorem.
The implication (b)⇒ (a) is immediate using Lemma 8(a).

div.head: Interpretation of formulas
div.p: In this subsection, we will consider some fixed frame M for the language J (T ) defined in (10). As a special case, we will denote the set of contexts by M = W . This may consist of arbitrary elements of certain given type. Recall that in case of evaluating expressions, the elements w 0 ∈ W are specific functions w 0 : L -→ M .

Furthermore, we will consider a theory T in which formula (31) is its only axiom. Finally, we denote by I M p an interpretation for some assignment p to variables of J (T ). Namely, we will take p(w) = w 0 ∈ W . (ii) Interpretation of intension of a linguistic expression A is
div.formula: I M p (Int(A)) = I M p ( w x • A wx) = A : W -→ L M . (37
div.p: Clearly, A ∈ M is a function which assigns to each context w 0 ∈ W a fuzzy set in M . It follows from definition (17) that interpretation of extension of A in the context w 0 ∈ W is just the fuzzy set
div.formula: I M p (Ext(A)w) = A(w 0 ) ⊂ ∼ M .
div.p: (iii) Interpretation of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule ( 34) is
div.formula: I M p ( w w • x yR ww xy) = R : W × W -→ L M ×M ,
div.p: i.e., it is a function which assigns to each couple of contexts w 0 , w 0 ∈ W a fuzzy relation
div.formula: R(w 0 , w 0 ) ⊂ ∼ M ×M , that is, R ∈ M .
div.p: (iv) As a special case of (iii), interpretation of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule of form ( 26) is a function
div.formula: I M p ( w w • x y • A (o ) wx B (o ) w y) = R, (38
div.p: where
div.formula: I M p (U ) = I M p ( z • w y(∃x)(z wx & & & R ww xy)) = F : M -→ (L M ) W
div.p: that assigns to each intension I M p (z ) = z ∈ M the intension given by F (z)(w 0 , y) = u∈M (z(w 0 , u) ⊗ R(w 0 , w 0 , u, y)) (40) for all w 0 , w 0 ∈ W , y ∈ M . (vi) Let the interpretation of Int(A) be the function A in (37) and let the context w 0 ∈ W and the fuzzy set A(w 0 ) be fixed. Then the interpretation of the formula U • Int(A) in M is a function G : W -→ L M that to each context w 0 ∈ W assigns a fuzzy set given by the membership function

In other words, each context w 0 and each element y ∈ M are assigned the truth value given by (41). The fuzzy relation R occurring in (40) and (41) says that in each couple of contexts w 0 , w 0 ∈ W the elements u, y are in relation R (in some degree taken from L).
Let T be the above theory and M be a frame for J (T ). Furthermore, let us consider the interpretation
div.formula: I M p (Int(B)) = B : W -→ L M . Lemma 9.
div.p: If M is a model of T then for each couple of contexts w 0 , w 0 ∈ W the following equality holds true:
for all y ∈ M .
Proof. Immediately from the definition of interpretation of formula (31) due to 5.15 and the fact that ( 31) is true in the degree 1.

Note that (42) is a composition of fuzzy relations defined in (1). However, here it follows from interpretation of the formula of FTT which defines implicit construction of intension of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule.

div.head: Solvability and consistency
div.p: The following theorem verifies by logical means the idea of Perfilieva and Lehmke [34] about relation between solvability of fuzzy relation equations and consistency of the theory induced by them (recall that fuzzy relations stand behind interpretation of fuzzy IF-THEN rules). It is extended to systems of fuzzy IF-THEN rules in Section 6.
Theorem 3. Let the theory T, fuzzy sets A, B, R and a frame M for the language J (T ) be as in Section 5.15. Then the following is equivalent.
(a) For each couple of contexts w 0 , w 0 ∈ W the fuzzy relation equation
is solvable for the unknown fuzzy relation R(w 0 , w 0 ). 43) is solvable then (31) is true in the degree 1 and so, M is a model of T.
div.formula: (b) A frame M is a model of T. (c) The theory T is consistent. Proof. (a) ⇒ (b) If (
div.p: (b) ⇒ (c) due to completeness of FTT. (c) ⇒ (a) If T is consistent then it has a model, i.e., (31) is true in the degree 1 in it. Since M is a frame in which all constructions have been correctly done, we conclude that M is also a model of T. But then (43) is solvable in it.

On the basis of the previous discussion, we see that the explicit form (25) of intension of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule provides necessary and sufficient condition for the existence of its implicit form. But even more holds true. Recall that all the intensions are supposed to be normal.
Theorem 4. Let T , A, B be as above.
div.formula: (a) T ٛ w yB w y ≡ • w y(∃x)(A wx & & & •A wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B w y), (b) T ٛ w yB w y ≡ • w y(∃x)(A wx & & & A wx & & & B w y). Proof. (a) (L.1) T ٛB w y ≡ B w y (reflexivity, properties of FTT) (L.2) T ٛB w y ≡ (∃x)A wx ∧ ∧ ∧ B w y (normality of intension of A, properties of FTT) (L.3) T ٛB w y ≡ (∃x)(A wx ∧ ∧ ∧ B w y) (L.2., properties of FTT) (L.4) T ٛB w y ≡ (∃x)(A wx & & & •A wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B w y) (L.3., properties of FTT) (L.5) T ٛ(∀y)(B w y ≡ (∃x)(A wx & & & •A wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B w y)) (L.4., generalization) (L.6) T ٛ yB w y ≡ y(∃x)(A wx & & & •A wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B w y) (L.5., Lemma 1, axioms)
div.p: The rest follows from L.6 using rule of generalization and Lemma 1.
div.formula: (L.1) T ٛ(∃x)(A wx) 2 (normality assumption, Lemma 2(c)) (L.2) T ٛB w y ≡ B w y (reflexivity, properties of FTT) (L.3) T ٛB w y ≡ (∃x)(A wx) 2 & & & B w y (L.1, L.2, properties of FTT) (L.4) T ٛB w y ≡ (∃x)(A wx) & & & A wx) & & & B w y) (L.3, properties of FTT)
div.p: The rest is the same as in the case (a).
Theorem 5.
div.formula: (a) T ٛ Int(B) ≡ Û • Int(A), (b) T ٛ Int(B) ≡ Ȗ • Int(A).
div.p: Proof. (a) Using Lemma 8(a) and -conversion we show that
div.formula: T ٛ Û • Int(A) ≡ w y • (∃x)(A wx & & & A wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B w y).
div.p: Then use Theorem 4(a) and definition of Int(B). The proof of (b) is analogous.
It follows from this theorem, that the explicit definition of intension of a fuzzy IF-THEN rule taken either as R I or R A is also its implicit definition.
Let Int(R) ≡ w w x y • R ww xy be a normal intension. The following theorem is a simple consequence of Lemma 2(a), (b). Theorem 6. Let u 0 ∈ Form be a new constant and put
div.formula: T = T ∪ {(∀w)(∀w )(∃y) R ww u 0 y}. Then T ٛ(∀w)(∀w ) • R ww u 0 ( y • R ww u 0 y) (44
div.p: and T is a conservative extension of T.
Proof. Formula (44) is obtained using rule of generalization.

According to this theorem, if an element u 0 from the kernel of the fuzzy set represented by a formula x(∃y) R ww xy is given for each couple of contexts w, w then it is in relation R with the element y • R ww u 0 y. Recall that the operator y is interpreted as a defuzzification. Consequently, this theorem verifies what we expect-that the defuzzification gives an element which is in relation characterized by a fuzzy IF-THEN rule and so, it can be taken as a result of reasoning based on the latter.

div.head: Systems of fuzzy IF-THEN rules
div.p: In this section, we will focus on systems of fuzzy IF-THEN rules; we will call them linguistic descriptions. The ground, of course, will be the interpretation of one rule developed above. As one can expect, the situation is more complicated because there raise more possibilities how to grasp this problem. One possibility is to take a linguistic description as a text consisting of separate rules. The general topic is the same but semantically, the linguistic description leads to a set of intensions rather than to one specific intension only. We will speak about explicit intension in this case. The second possibility is to seek a certain hidden intension of the whole linguistic description. This will be called implicit intension and we will show that this may not always exist. There is also a possibility to join rules forming the linguistic description by a connective ('and' or 'or') and take it as one (long) sentence that, of course, has its own intension. However, this intension may be different from the implicit intension. Conditions for existence of an implicit intension are studied. This question turns out to be related with the old problem of solving fuzzy relation equations studied in the fuzzy set literature (see the citations).

div.head: Linguistic description and its interpretation
div.p: Let us consider a system of fuzzy IF-THEN rules
div.formula: R 1 = IF X is A 1 THEN Y is B 1 , R 2 = IF X is A 2 THEN Y is B 2 , . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . R m = IF X is A m THEN Y is B m . (45
div.p: If all A, B's are evaluating linguistic expressions then this system can be understood as a description of some strategy (e.g., control or decision-making), behaviour of a system, etc. Therefore, we will call system (45) a linguistic description and denote it by LD. We can also understand it as a special text.

The problem now is how such a linguistic description should be analysed, what does it provide? In correspondence with the explanation above, (45) can be seen from two sides: first, each rule is a compound evaluating expression which has its own intension and thus, the linguistic description is a set of intensions providing us with some knowledge. We will speak about explicit knowledge coming out of the linguistic description, or simply, explicit knowledge from the linguistic description.

Second, the linguistic description as a whole represents a certain kind of a relation raising from the intensions of all the evaluating expressions occurring in (45). We will speak about implicit knowledge from the linguistic description.
In the sequel, we will need the following special formula:
div.formula: Eval o( ) := w x z (∃z o )(Υ z o & & & •z o ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ z wx ). (46
div.p: Let Int(A) be intension of some evaluating expression A. We say that an element x in the context w is evaluated by the expression A if the following formula is provable:
div.formula: T ٛEval o( ) • wx Int(A).(47)
div.p: In other words, since Υ z o means that z o is a non-zero truth value, (47) says that the truth value of the statement "x in the context w has the property named by A" is non-zero.

div.head: Explicit knowledge from the linguistic description
div.p: In this case, the linguistic description is simply a list of intensions
each of them defined in (26) and formed within a language J (T ) of some theory T. We will write LD A if all rules R have form (23) and LD I if all rules R have form (25).

The problem raises, how can we utilize (48) in logical theory? Namely, intensions are not formulas of type o and so, they cannot be explicitly used in formal proofs. Is there some way how a specific knowledge contained in (48) can be grasped? The clue lays in two observations: For example, from the rule 'IF X is small THEN Y is big' we know that "if a value of X is small then there is a value of Y that is certainly big".
These observations can be formalized as follows.

We conclude that the explicit knowledge means that the linguistic description provides lists of formulas (50) and (51), or (49) and (52) (depending on the form of fuzzy IF-THEN rules occurring in LD) that are of type o and that must be provable in T. Such a theory T will be called a theory determined by the linguistic description LD. Note also that we cannot take in fuzzy logic the considered list of formulas as conjunction of them because of existence of two different conjunction connectives (cf. [26,27]).

If one wishes, he/she may take (50) and (51), or (49) and (52) as axioms of T. In general, however, this is unnecessary since we only need these formulas to be provable in T disregarding the way, how they have been proved. Therefore, we will not specify the theory T precisely and focus only on some properties which should be fulfilled by it.
Furthermore, the text is a set of sentences and so, we may distinguish its topic and focus (cf. Section 3.3). Namely, the topic of a linguistic description is a set of intensions
div.formula: Topic LD = {Int(A j ) | j = 1, . . . , m}. (53
div.p: This means that the topic is determined by the set of linguistic predications, each of them forming the first part the respective fuzzy IF-THEN rule. Similarly, its focus is
div.formula: Focus LD = {Int(B j ) | j = 1, . . . , m}.(54)
div.p: Note that the common characteristics both for the topic as well as for the focus of a linguistic description, which ties together all the fuzzy IF-THEN rules present in it, are the variables X and Y, respectively.

div.head: Linguistic description consisting of implications
div.p: In this section, we will take fuzzy IF-THEN rules in the linguistic description as logical implications. Let w be some concrete context w. For tangibility, we will introduce a constant w 0 to represent it and a constant u 0 ∈ Form to represent some definite element. With respect to T, we may suppose that these are new constant symbols added to the language J (T ). We will also introduce a new constant b 0 i ∈ Form o and put T ٛb 0 i ≡ A ,i w 0 u 0 for some concrete i ∈ {1, . . . , m}.
The following theorem with quite simple essence shows what can be derived from the assumptions of Section 6.2.
Theorem 7. Let T be a theory determined by the linguistic description LD I . Furthermore, let T ٛΥ b 0 i for some i and let ŷ / ∈ J (T ) be a new constant of type . Then
div.formula: (a) T ٛŷ ≡ y • b 0 i ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B ,i w y. (b) T ٛ(∀w ) • Eval o( ) w ŷ • Int(B i ) where Int(B i ) ∈ Focus LD . (c) T ٛ(∀w )Υ (B ,i w ŷ).
div.p: Proof. For all j = 1, . . . , m, we have (L.1) T ٛ(∀w)(∀x)(∃y) (A j, wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B j, w y) (normality assumption) (L.2) T ٛ(∃y) (A j, w 0 u 0 ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B j, w y) (L.1, substitution) (L.3) T ٛb 0 i ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B ,i w ŷ (L.2, Lemma 2(a)) This proves (a). Furthermore, for all j = 1, . . . , m:
div.formula: (L.1) T ٛA j, w 0 u 0 ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B ,j w y( y • A ,j w 0 u 0 ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B ,j w y) (L.2 above, Lemma 2(b), substitution) (L.2) T ٛΥ b 0 i & & &(b 0 i ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B ,i w ŷ) (L.3 above, assumption, properties of FTT) (L.3) T ٛ Int(B i ) ≡ w yB ,i w y (definition of intension) (L.4) T ٛ(∃z o ) • Υ z o & & &(z o ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B ,i w ŷ) (L.2, substitution, modus ponens) (L.5) T ٛB ,i w ŷ ≡ ( w yB ,i w y)w ŷ (L.3, -conversion) (L.6) T ٛ(∃y o ) • Υ z o & & &(z o ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ Int(B i )w ŷ) (L.4, L.5, properties of FTT, definition of Int(B i )) (L.7) T ٛ(∀w ) • Eval o( ) w ŷ • Int(B i ) (L.6, definition of Eval, generalization)
div.p: The fact that Int(B i ) ∈ Focus LD follows from the definition of linguistic description and its focus and line L.3 that has been derived from (49).
(c) follows from Lemma 2(g).

This theorem has the following interpretation. Let us consider a linguistic description LD I (i.e., the fuzzy IF-THEN rules are implications). Let u 0 represent an element that is in the context w 0 evaluated by a concrete linguistic expression Int(A i ) from the topic of LD I in a non-zero degree. Then we may use the corresponding fuzzy IF-THEN rule R i and find an element represented by a constant ŷi that is evaluated by the linguistic expression B i in every context w , where Int(B i ) ∈ Focus LD . This element is the result of our reasoning based on the given linguistic description and it depends on u 0 , w 0 and Int(A i ). Of course, in a given model of T, it may vary depending on the context w , but it is always determined.

The problem is, how the linguistic expression Int(A i ) can be found on the basis of the given u 0 and w 0 . We speak about perception of u 0 and the whole procedure is called perception-based logical deduction. It is in more details described in [22].

div.head: Implicit knowledge from the linguistic description
div.p: When seeing a linguistic description as a text, we may take it as a certain complicated property having its own intension. Then the following question arises: does such intension exist? Under which conditions it can be formed and what are its properties?

Let a linguistic description LD be given and consider the formula Ū in (33). Furthermore, let T ٛU ≡ Ū( ) R . We say that the formula R represents an implicit knowledge contained in the linguistic description LD if
div.formula: T ٛ Int(B i ) ≡ U • Int(A i ) (55)
div.p: holds for all the linguistic expressions forming the fuzzy IF-THEN rules R i , i = 1, . . . , m in the linguistic description LD. Hence, the implicit knowledge can be, in accordance with Section 5.12, considered as a kind of implicit intension of the whole linguistic description LD. Note that, analogously to Lemma 7, (55) is equivalent to
div.formula: T ٛB i, w y ≡ (∃x)(A i, wx & & & R ww xy), i = 1, . . . , m.(56)
div.p: Analogously to Section 8, we denote
div.formula: Û := Ū( ) • m j =1 A j, wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B j, w y, Ȗ := Ū( ) • m j =1 A j, wx & & & B j, w y. Obviously, (a) T ٛ Û ≡ z w y • (∃x)(z wx & & & m j =1 A j, wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B j, w y). (b) T ٛ Ȗ ≡ z w y • (∃x)(z wx & & & m j =1 A j, wx & & & B j, w y).
div.p: The following theorem is a syntactic and very general form of the main result in fuzzy relation equations theory, originally proved by Sanchez in [36]. Other authors who significantly contributed to it are, for example DiNola et al. [4], Gottwald [8], Gottwald et al. [9], Klawonn [12], Novák et al. [30], Perfilieva and Lehmke [34], Perfilieva and Tonis [35] and others.
div.formula: T ٛ(∃x)(A wx & & & R ww xy) ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ (∃x) A wx & & & m i=1 A i, wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B i, w y .
div.p: From this and ( 35) we obtain From our point of view, the above theorem demonstrates that an implicit intension of a linguistic description need not exist. Its existence depends on the way, how formulas A i, , B i, comply with the requirement that U must be a strongly extensional function-cf. Section 5.13.
div.formula: T ٛB w y ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ (∃x) A wx & & & m i=1 A i, wx ⇒ ⇒ ⇒ B i, w y .
div.p: Analogously to Section 5.16, we may formulate the following theorem.

Theorem 9. Let T be a theory in which formulas (55), i = 1, . . . , m are its only axioms. Let M be a frame for the language J (T ) and I M p be interpretation for some assignment p to variables. Let A i , B i , R, i = 1, . . . , m be functions constructed similarly as in Section 5.15. Then the following is equivalent.
(a) A frame M is a model of T. (b) For each couple of contexts w 0 , w 0 ∈ W the system of fuzzy relation equations
is solvable for the unknown fuzzy relation R(w 0 , w 0 ). (c) The theory T is consistent.
The following theorem characterizes conditions when the conjunctive form of fuzzy IF-THEN rules represents implicit knowledge in the linguistic description.

Theorem 10. Let T ٛ(∀w)(∃x)A i, wx for all i = 1, . . . , m. Then the following is equivalent. It follows from this theorem that if a system of fuzzy IF-THEN rules has an implicit intension then nearness (in the sense of the fuzzy equality ≡) of intensions Int(A i ) and Int(A j ) necessarily implies also nearness of the corresponding intensions Int(B i ) and Int(B j ).

div.head: Outline of further development
div.p: It follows from the above analysis that fuzzy IF-THEN rules can be seen as linguistic (i.e., surface) representations of special formulas of fuzzy intensional logic. When taken in this way, they lead to formal theories with special properties. This opens a wide field for pure logical study. Various specific concepts may thus be introduced, for example as follows.

Let T be a consistent theory based on LD in the sense of Section 6.2. Let R 0 / ∈ LD be a new fuzzy IF-THEN rule. Then R 0 extends LD if T ∪ { w yB w y ≡ w yU A } is consistent where A , B interpret adjectival predications in the antecedent and succedent of R, respectively. A theory T is maximal if there is no fuzzy IF-THEN rule R which extends it. We may now study conditions under which this is possible.
We may also study ways of deriving conclusions from linguistic descriptions. A specific principle is perception-based logical deduction described in [22,28].
Interesting problem raises when realizing that we may consider also compound linguistic expressions of the form R := R I 1 and • • • and R I m , (59)
div.formula: Ȓ := R A 1 or • • • or R A m . (60
div.p: We may find explicit intensions of these expressions in the way analogous to that described in Sections 5. However, intensions (61) or (62) need not be equivalent to the implicit intensions considered in Section 6.4 and further.

Conditions for existence of the latter, relation between explicit and implicit intensions, their deduction potential, and other questions should be studied. Is there a difference between (45), and (59) or (60) (alternatively, in terms of intensions, between (48) and (61) or (62))? The answer is yes: (45) is a text consisting of separate sentences while (59) or (60) are specific compound expressions whose parts (i.e., fuzzy IF-THEN rules) are set to be related to each other using a specific connective, namely 'and' or 'or'. Thus, the latter is a stronger proposition than the former. We see from Section 6 that (59) and (60) are linguistic characterizations of strongly extensional functions. Unfortunately, this is a rather big limitation and we will demonstrate elsewhere that the use of evaluating linguistic expressions is in most realistic situations excluded (cf. [20]).
Note that interpretation of (61) and ( 62) are functions that assign to each couple of contexts w 0 , w 0 ∈ W one of the respective fuzzy relations (A j (w 0 , u) ⊗ B j (w 0 , v)), (64
where A j (w 0 ) ⊂ ∼ M , B j (w 0 ) ⊂ ∼ M , j = 1, . . . , m and A j (w 0 , u), B j (w 0 , v) are the corresponding membership degrees for u, v ∈ M .

div.head: Disregarding natural language
div.p: Let us briefly discuss the relation between the interpretation of fuzzy IF-THEN rules as presented in the literature on fuzzy set theory (cf. [2,10,16,[32][33][34]) and the theory developed in this paper.

The essential difference lays in taking fuzzy IF-THEN rules as a specific way for description of a function and ignoring their character as natural language expressions. Namely, the whole linguistic description is assigned one of two possible formulas of first-order fuzzy logic: DNF(x, y) = where DNF stands for disjunctive, and CNF for conjunctive normal form because due to Perfilieva [31][32][33][34], these forms are obtained as generalization of the corresponding classical concepts. There are no special requirements on the formulas A j (x), B j (y) from the point of view of linguistics. It should be noted that in practice, most frequent is (65).
Then the formula

corresponds to our implicit knowledge from linguistic description (cf. Section 6.4) and its interpretation is called Mamdani (or Mamdani-Assilian) rule of inference (the connective & & & is often interpreted by minimum)-cf. [3,14].

In the light of Section 5.15, (65) and (66) correspond to (62) and (61) when a couple of contexts w 0 , w 0 ∈ W is fixed with the interpretation being one of the respective fuzzy relations (64) and (63). It is significant, that another interpretation of (65) and ( 66) is obtained when changing the model while in case of (62) and (61), another interpretation is obtained in the same model when changing the contexts w 0 , w 0 . Still more can be obtained when changing also the model. Moreover, FTT includes predicate fuzzy logic 7 and so, everything proved in the latter can be proved also in FTT. Consequently, our theory of fuzzy IF-THEN rules is more general and comprehensive.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, we made a step to the development of a concise formal theory of fuzzy IF-THEN rules. This theory should encompass the formal theories based on fuzzy predicated logics as well as theories focusing only on semantical models. The outcome of our approach is a high generality which enables us to cover not only technical side of the rules, but also to model their meaning when taken as special expressions of natural language. We are confident that eventually all relevant knowledge about fuzzy inference methods based on fuzzy IF-THEN rule bases will be represented, formalized and backed up by proof within the well-founded logical representation presented here. Thus, we get closer to the ability to equip robots with intelligence so that they could understand, at least, part of our language and process linguistic instructions in a way analogous to the way how people normally do it. 8

note.p: Informally, a phrase is a group of words in a sentence that functions somewhat like as single word.
The symbol ":=" should be read as "is defined by", or simply "is".

The difference between the two conjunctions ∧ ∧ ∧ and & & & (disjunctions ∨ ∨ ∨, ∇ ∇ ∇) comes out from their mathematical interpretation and their role in the formal theory. The conjunction & & & (sometimes called strong conjunction) must be used when combining formulas in modus ponens while ∧ ∧ ∧ has rather auxiliary role. From the linguistic point of view, ∧ ∧ ∧ is a phrasal conjunction (∨ ∨ ∨ is a phrasal disjunction), i.e., it should primarily be used for joining phrases. The strong conjunction & & & (disjunction ∇ ∇ ∇) is sentential, i.e., it should be used for joining sentences. However, precise theory giving rules, how and where these connectives should be used is not yet elaborated.
For example, (A(w0 ) → B(w 0 ))(u, v) = A(w 0 )(u) → B(w 0 )(v) for all u, v ∈ M .
The systems of FTT are developed also for richer structures of truth values than IMTL , e.g., Łukasiewicz -, BL -or Ł -algebras-see[23].
See, e.g.,[5,19,22] for steps that have already been done towards this goal.
